Declaration-of-the-Right-to-Stutter.title: Declaration of the Right to Stutter
Declaration-of-the-Right-to-Stutter.content:
We, the undersigned, declare that people who stutter should be accepted as having a stutter. We may, or may not, choose to find support to sound fluent or stutter less. That is our right. It is not reasonable to expect or insist that we sound fluent. We stutter. That is how we talk.
 
In this time of diversity, adjustments are too often not given to those who stutter, be it at work, education or using everyday services. The expectation is rather that we should strive to ‘overcome’ our stutter and speak differently. As individuals we may wish, and even try, to do so. But as a community we refute the idea that we all stop stuttering.
 
No organization can claim to value equality or diversity unless stuttering voices are permitted and valued. We call upon every organization and institution to work with people who stutter to make sure that all of us are given the respect every person deserves; and that space is made for us.
 
It is our right to speak as we do.
www.stamily.org/declaration

NLSA Research & Accessibility Project
Welcome to a growing collection of notes on accessibility, stuttering,
and sociolinguistic research in Newfoundland and Labrador.

learn/community-workshops.title: Community Workshops
learn/community-workshops.content:
Community Workshops
Community workshops are a central part of the Accessibility Project. These workshops create shared spaces for people who stutter (PWS), families, educators, clinicians, and community partners to come together, learn from one another, and collectively imagine more communicatively accessible communities in Newfoundland and Labrador.
Rather than treating accessibility as a technical problem to be solved by experts alone, the workshops are designed as collaborative spaces where lived experience, professional knowledge, and community insight all carry equal weight.

What Happens in a Workshop?
Each workshop is structured around three core goals:
1. Listening to Lived Experience
Participants hear directly from people who stutter about:

Navigating healthcare, education, and public life
Experiences of stigma, misunderstanding, and support
What accessibility feels like in everyday interaction

2. Understanding Communication as Accessibility
We explore:

Communication differences as part of human diversity
How institutions often privilege fluency and speed
How everyday interactional norms can unintentionally exclude

3. Building Local Strategies
Together, we:

Identify concrete barriers in local contexts
Share existing community strengths
Co-design small, realistic changes that improve accessibility


Who Are the Workshops For?
Workshops are open to:

People who stutter (youth and adults)
Parents and family members
Teachers and school staff
Speech-language pathologists and healthcare workers
Employers and community organizers
Policy and service stakeholders

Each workshop is adapted to the needs and interests of the local community.

Workshop Locations
We are hosting workshops across Newfoundland and Labrador, including:

gander
corner-brook
happy-valley-goose-bay
labrador city
st-johns

Each location page documents:

Local themes
Participant questions
Accessibility priorities
Emerging action ideas


Accessibility Commitments
Our workshops prioritize:

Flexible participation formats
No pressure to speak
Respect for disfluency
Clear communication pacing
Multiple ways to contribute (speaking, writing, listening)

Accessibility is treated not as an accommodation, but as a shared responsibility.

Outcomes of the Workshops
Insights from the workshops directly inform:

Survey and interview interpretation
Community-facing resources
Policy conversations
Training materials
The evolving definition of communicative accessibility in NL


Join a Workshop
If you would like to attend, host, or help shape a workshop in your community, please contact the Newfoundland and Labrador Stuttering Association (NLSA) info@nlstuttering.ca or project lead pauldd@mun.ca.
Workshops are free, collaborative, and community-driven.

This page will continue to grow as workshops take place and new communities join the project.

learn/ethics-and-values.title: Ethics & Values
learn/ethics-and-values.content:
Ethics & Values
This project is grounded in ethical, collaborative, and justice-oriented research practices.
Our work is guided by:

TCPS2 ethical principles
Community-based research frameworks
Disability justice perspectives
Dialogic approaches to communication

People who stutter are not positioned as research “subjects,” but as:

Partners
Co-researchers
Knowledge holders

We treat accessibility not as an accommodation added later, but as a core research principle from the outset.

learn/interviews.title: Interviews
learn/interviews.content:
Interviews
Semi-structured interviews form the second phase of the project.
Interviews explore:

Personal communication histories
Encounters with healthcare and education
Experiences of stigma and support
Navigating public life as a person who stutters

Interviews are conducted using accessible, participant-centred protocols. Participants control:

Pacing
Question selection
Modes of response
Levels of disclosure

learn/methods-overview.title: Methods Overview
learn/methods-overview.content:
Methods Overview
The Accessibility Project uses a mixed-methods, community-engaged research design. Our approach prioritizes:

Lived experience as expertise
Ethical collaboration
Accessibility as both a method and an outcome
Transparency across all stages of research

The project unfolds in multiple phases:

A province-wide survey
Semi-structured interviews
Community meetings and workshops
Knowledge mobilization through media, events, and public engagement

Each phase informs the next, allowing the project to remain responsive to community needs.

learn/survey.title: Survey
learn/survey.content:
Survey
The project begins with a province-wide survey designed to assess:

Access to speech-language pathology services
Barriers to participation
Experiences in schools, healthcare, and workplaces
Community and policy gaps

The survey is open to:

People who stutter
Family members
Clinicians
Educators
Community stakeholders

Findings from the survey guide the interview phase and the community meetings.

start-here/what-this-project-is.title: What This Project Is
start-here/what-this-project-is.content:
What This Project Is
The Accessibility Project is a multi-stage research and community-engagement initiative focused on identifying and removing barriers to full participation for people who stutter (PWS) in Newfoundland and Labrador.
We are building a coalition across health care, education, community groups, and lived-experience advocates to understand:

Where accessibility gaps exist
How PWS navigate services and communication environments
What supports are missing
How communities can become more inclusive

This site provides an evolving, transparent view into the research process, our methods, our partners, and the outcomes of this work.

start-here/who-we-are.title: Who We Are
start-here/who-we-are.content:
Who We Are
This project is a collaboration among:

People who stutter (PWS)
Newfoundland and Labrador Stuttering Association (NLSA)
Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN)
Educators, clinicians, policymakers, and community allies

Our team is committed to ethical, community-engaged, and accessible research.
We combine sociolinguistics, disability studies, lived experience, and qualitative research methods to build a more inclusive province for people who communicate differently.

start-here/why-accessibility-matters.title: Why Accessibility Matters in NL
start-here/why-accessibility-matters.content:
Why Accessibility Matters in Newfoundland and Labrador
People who stutter (PWS) often face structural, communicative, and attitudinal barriers across health services, schools, workplaces, and public life.
In Newfoundland and Labrador, accessibility gaps are shaped by:

Limited public speech-language pathology services
Uneven access across rural and urban regions
Cultural narratives surrounding communication and fluency
A lack of policy frameworks that include communication disability

Understanding these barriers is essential to building a province where PWS can participate fully, be heard, and experience dignity in communication.
This project places PWS at the centre of the conversation, using collaborative and justice-oriented research practices.
